Front: What is Plato’s Theory of Forms?
Back: The belief that non-physical Forms (perfect ideals) are the ultimate reality.

Front: What is the Form of the Good?
Back: The highest Form which gives truth and knowledge to all other Forms.

Front: What is Plato’s analogy of the cave?
Back: A metaphor showing humans mistaking sensory experience for true reality.

Front: What is Plato’s view of the soul?
Back: The soul is immortal and more real than the body.

Front: What are the three parts of Plato’s soul?
Back: Reason, spirit, appetite.

Front: What is Aristotle’s Four Causes theory?
Back: Material, formal, efficient and final causes explain existence.
An unmoved mover that causes motion without being moved.
Explanation by reference to purpose or design.
Argument from motion leading to an unmoved mover.
Argument from causation leading to a first cause.
Argument from contingency leading to a necessary being.

Front: What is the Kalam Cosmological Argument?
Back: Everything that begins has a cause; the universe began; therefore it has a cause.

Front: What is Leibniz’s Principle of Sufficient Reason?
Back: Everything must have an explanation.

Front: What was Hume’s criticism of causation?
Back: We cannot observe necessary connection, only constant conjunction.

Front: What was Russell’s response to the cosmological argument?
Back: The universe may just be a brute fact.
God is that than which nothing greater can be conceived.
The perfect island analogy challenges Anselm.

Front: What was Kant’s objection to the Ontological Argument?
Back: Existence is not a predicate.

Front: What is Descartes’ version of the Ontological Argument?
Back: Existence is a necessary property of a perfect being.
Design implies a designer like a watch implies a watchmaker.
The teleological argument based on purpose in nature.

Front: What impact did Darwin have on design arguments?
Back: Evolution undermined the need for a designer.
Physical constants are precisely set for life.
Multiple universes explain apparent fine-tuning.
Multiple arguments together increase probability of God.

Front: What is William James’ view of religious experience?
Back: Religious experiences are authoritative for the individual.

Front: What is Otto’s concept of the numinous?
Back: Experience of the wholly other, mysterious and awe-inspiring.
Experiences shared by a group.
Private mystical encounters.

Front: What is Freud’s view of religion?
Back: Religion is an illusion rooted in psychological need.

Front: What is the Logical Problem of Evil?
Back: God’s attributes are inconsistent with evil.

Front: What is the Evidential Problem of Evil?
Back: The quantity of evil makes God unlikely.
God is omnipotent, omnibenevolent, evil exists.
Evil is privation; caused by misuse of free will.
Evil is necessary for soul-making.
Suffering develops moral character.

Front: What is the Free Will Defence?
Back: God allows evil to preserve free will.

Front: What is Process Theology’s view of God?
Back: God is not omnipotent in the classical sense.
Mind and body are separate substances.
I think therefore I am.
Only physical matter exists.

Front: What is Dawkins’ view of the soul?
Back: The soul is an illusion.
Bodily life after death restored by God.
Experiences reported close to death.
A statement is meaningful only if empirically verifiable.
A statement must be capable of being proven false.

Front: What was Flew’s invisible gardener analogy?
Back: Religious claims become meaningless if unfalsifiable.

Front: What is Aquinas’ analogy of attribution?
Back: Language about God is partly similar.

Front: What is Aquinas’ analogy of proportion?
Back: Words applied to God proportionally reflect divine qualities.
Describing God by what He is not.

Front: What is Boethius’ view of eternity?
Back: God exists outside time.

Front: What is Anselm’s view of eternity?
Back: God is timeless.

Front: What is Swinburne’s view of God and time?
Back: God exists within time.
All-powerful.
All-knowing.
All-loving.
Is something good because God commands it?
God is not composed of parts.
Language expresses meaning metaphorically.

Front: What is analogy in religious language?
Back: Words applied to God in qualified sense.
Symbolic story conveying truth.
Truth of religious claims verified after death.

Front: What is Plato’s view of immortality?
Back: Soul pre-exists and survives body.

Front: What is Aristotle’s view of the soul?
Back: Soul is the form of the body.
God recreates individuals after death.
Study of paranormal phenomena.
Defence of God regarding natural evil.
Evil from natural processes.
Evil from human actions.
Freedom without determinism.
All events caused by prior events.
Free will compatible with causation.
Movement applying verification principle.
Focus on human freedom and responsibility.
Meaning depends on use in context.

Front: What is Aquinas’ view of natural theology?
Back: God known through reason.

Front: What is Barth’s view of revelation?
Back: God known only through revelation.

Front: What is Aquinas’ view on faith and reason?
Back: Faith and reason are compatible.

Front: What is Hume’s critique of miracles?
Back: Miracles violate natural laws.

Front: What is Swinburne’s defence of miracles?
Back: Testimony can justify belief.
Based on reason alone.
Based on experience.
If premises true, conclusion must follow.
Conclusion probable not certain.
True in all possible worlds.
Could have been otherwise.
Prefer simpler explanations.
Do not multiply entities unnecessarily.
God exists independently of belief.
God exists only as human construct.

Front: What is the Copleston-Russell debate about?
Back: Contingency and existence of God.

Front: What is the significance of Plato for Christianity?
Back: Influenced dualism and immortality.

Front: What is the significance of Aristotle for Aquinas?
Back: Provided philosophical framework.
Connecting philosophy with ethics and theology.
Knowledge and understanding.
Analysis and evaluation.
